In linguistics, an unaccusative verb is an intransitive verb whose syntactic argument is not a semantic agent; that is, it does not actively initiate, or is not actively responsible for, the action of the [MASK]; or it treats the argument like the accusative argument of a transitive verb.

With other amines such as piperidine the ring-opened compound after loss of hydrogen bromide to the nitrile is also the isolated reaction product: More evidence is gained by isotope labeling with deuterium at C5: The deuterium atom is no longer present in the reaction product and this is again explained by the ANRORC mechanism where the ring-opened intermediate 4 is a tautomeric pair enabling fast H-D exchange: The final piece of evidence is provided by an isotope scrambling experiment with both [MASK] atoms in the pyrimidine core replaced by the 14N isotope to a degree of 3% each: In the final product 4 (reversed to the reactant, after acid hydrolysis and bromination of 2) roughly half the isotope content is lost, clearly demonstrating that one internal nitrogen atom has been displaced to an external nitrogen atom.

Taiga (/ˈtaɪɡə/; Russian: тайга́; [tɐjˈɡa]; from Turkic) also known as boreal [MASK] or snow forest, is a biome characterized by coniferous forests consisting mostly of pines, spruces and larches.
Taiga (/ˈtaɪɡə/; Russian: тайга́; [tɐjˈɡa]; from Turkic) also known as boreal forest or snow [MASK], is a biome characterized by coniferous forests consisting mostly of pines, spruces and larches.

For example, the taiga of North America mostly consists of spruces; Scandinavian and Finnish taiga consists of a mix of spruce, pines and birch; Russian taiga has spruces, pines and larches depending on the region, while the Eastern Siberian taiga is a vast larch [MASK].

A different use of the term taiga is often encountered in the English language, with "boreal [MASK]" used in the United States and Canada to refer to only the more southerly part of the biome, while "taiga" is used to describe the more barren areas of the northernmost part of the biome approaching the tree line and the tundra biome.
Although at high elevations taiga grades into alpine tundra through Krummholz, it is not an alpine biome only like subalpine [MASK], and much of taiga is lowlands.

A multistage (or multi-stage) rocket is a [MASK] that usestwo or more stages, each of which contains its own engines and propellant.

Two-stage rockets are quite common, but rockets with as many as five separate stages have been successfully launched.By jettisoning stages when they run out of propellant, the mass of the remaining [MASK] is decreased.
This staging allows the thrust of the remaining stages to more easily accelerate the [MASK] to its final speed and height.
In the typical case, the first-stage and booster engines fire to propel the entire [MASK] upwards.
When the boosters run out of fuel, they are detached from the rest of the [MASK] (usually with some kind of small explosive charge) and fall away.
This leaves a smaller [MASK], with the second stage on the bottom, which then fires.

Yaoi derives from two sources; in the early 1970s, shōjo [MASK] magazines published tanbi (aesthetic) stories, also known as shōnen ai (boy love), featuring platonic relationships between young boys.
The other influence began in the dōjinshi (fan fiction) markets of Japan in the late 1970s as yaoi, a sexualized parody of popular shōnen [MASK] and anime stories.

In Japan, the term yaoi continues to refer mainly to parody dōjinshi; among Western fans, however, yaoi is used as a generic term for female-oriented [MASK], anime, dating sims, novels and fan fiction works featuring idealized gay male relationships.

Costochondritis, also known as chest wall pain, costosternal [MASK], or costosternal chondrodynia is an acute and often temporary inflammation of the costal cartilage, the structure that connects each rib to the sternum at the costosternal joint.
Severe cases of costal cartilage inflammation that also involve painful swelling are sometimes referred to as Tietze's [MASK], a term sometimes used interchangeably with costochondritis.
However, some physicians view costochondritis and Tietze's [MASK] as separate disease states due to the absence of costal cartilage swelling in costochondritis.

In linguistics, a verb phrase (VP) is a syntactic unit composed of at least one [MASK] and its dependents—objects, complements and other modifiers—but not always including the subject.

A propaganda film is a film that involves some form of [MASK].
